Posts.Title: Lymph nodes again/mattered nodes Mamita49 lexislove

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 01:18PM sedosa wrote: I am glad you began this thread.  If is important for people to know that rads are NOT a piece of cake.  Everyone had prepared me for an easy go of it and i thought i was nuts and imagining my symptoms.  I had rt side mx on 2/14/07.  Began chemo 3/30/07   6 Taxotere/Carbolaitin along with Herceptin.  this was interrupted end of April due to massive infection that nearly killed me.  Finished chemo on 8/16/07 , began arimidex and returned to work on  8/23/07.  Wound was still open so rads were postponed.  Began rads on 10/31/07 was able to work three weeks.  The fatigue was incredible, much worse than that of chemo.  Also my emotions were really screwed.  I was crying all the time.Left work at thanksgiving.  Rads completed on 12/16/07.  Was able to return to work on Jan 2 ,2008/  Generally I have been okay. but occasionally am hit with a fatigue so powerful that i want to collapse.  I find it hard to focus from time to time and have decided to retire in June.  Hope to catch up on sleep and regain some health at that time.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 07:43PM sedosa wrote: Hi sailor, Sorry you are part of our club, but you have come to the correct place. You have to make the decision with which you are most comfortable. Have you spoken with an oncologist yet? A double mastectomy sounds like a good way to get rid of the problem permanently, but it is very serious surgery and shouldn't be taken lightly;You have caught this cancer very early and it is non invasive. See what your oncologist recommends. Read as much as you can and then make a decision. I was given the choice of lumpectomy or mastectomy and I chose mastectomy for the same reason you are expressing, however, mine was stage 3 grade 3 invasive. I have undergone chemo and am presently involved in radiation. So far there has been no sign of recurrence. Wishing you the best on your sailing. steffi

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 06:45PM sedosa wrote: I am glad to read this thread.  I also was one who asked the wrong questions.  I still am unsure of posting on stage iv even if it is in response to what a dear friend has posted.  I personally would like some guidelines.  I would never want to hurt any of my sisters.  People (and I) say stupid things, but it is attitude that counts.  If some one tells me to be strong, my hackles go up, but i try to see if she is really caring or just mouthing words.  I can never feel the same pain my sisters feel, but I can own my own pain.  steffi
Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 08:30PM sedosa wrote: Amber, Please don't quit.  I just found you again.  I read you all the time when we were going through rads.  You really kept me going.  I am so sorry you are feeling overwhelmed.  I have felt as you do.  A dear friend shared a thought with me that helped me dig out of the depths of depression and wanting to give up.  He said,  despair is putting limits on the power of God.  We say we know how things will turn out without letting God work his plan.  You are such an inspiration to so many. Keep on keeping on.  BEING is just as important as DOING.  I saw this when my mother was in the nursing home. She had dementia.  She knew no one's name, she was blind and confined to a wheel chair, among other difficulties.  But she had an effect on so many workers that  came by her room.  She would just utter a few words, "you are so beautiful today", god bless you dear"  just words.  But so many were encouraged.  One of the cooks told me that she had to go to mom's room every day to get her fix.  Amber you give us a fix.  We are here to hold you up.    It is ok to feel down and I am glad you cn express it so well. Hugs, Sed
Posts.Title: I am ready to quit.... mrs_X_Sunneedazee lovinmomma

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2007 08:26PM - edited Dec 3, 2007 08:30PM by sedosa Hi IrishSteph, Glad to meet you. Sorry it has to be through this means. The shaking and worry is very normal and we all have done it. Bx means biopsy, dx = diagnosis, bc= breast cancer, tx=treatment. Just remember you have a 90% chance of not needing any of these abbreviations. Two things about your letters caught my eye. One, your name Steph, I am Steph also. You have several times called yourself a wimp. I always feel as if I am a wimp. However when I step back and look at it what I call a wimp is just expressing that I feel scared or that I hurt. That is NOT a wimp (i tell myself). That is just expressing feelings. Somewhere along the line of our upbringing you and I got the idea that expressing feelings is being a wimp. It is not. You have come to a very safe place to rant, cry or what ever. Your friends who say it is nothing do so because they also are scared, don't know what to say and hope it is nothing. I hope you keep telling us how you feel. We need to share this. We can't handle it alone. Also you will not be alone tonight or tomorrow night. You can write here or join the chat room. There are many ladies (and a few men) who are in so many different stages of this fight. Sometimes they are goofy and laugh a lot. It is good to see that people who are fighting cancer can laugh. I agree with the other ladies who advised getting some medication to help you through this. They really help. Ask for either antidepressants of anti anxiety medications. You will be glad you did. Friday will go much more smoothly. If you need a biopsy, you will be able to accept it with calm and because of this it will go much easier. The only pain is the quite small needle for numbing up. As far as decorating. jesus came to bring us hope. Try placing one small decoration out to show your hopes. Just remember we are with you all the way. Lots of hugs, dear. Steffi

Posts.Title: Pink Foam?? sedosa sedosa

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 08:28PM sedosa wrote: Diane, I too have had my faith seriously challenged through the birth of three children with serious health problems. I know God pulled me through those times. I was left to raise the three when the youngest was only three. Now many people remark that I did such a good job raising the kids. I know it was God. BUT when this cancer came and my sister was diagnosed the same day with an unkown cancer that was in her spine and hip, I was stunned so much all I could do was pray for her. I visited with her shortly after my mastectomy and she remarked," I have never prayed for health." I stopped and thought... neither have I. I still don't pray for my health. I guess it is because I really believe that I have no control over what is happening to me. I didn't do it, God didn't do it. It just is, because it is. The cancer will go away if it is meant to. I will die with cancer, as did my sis, or I won't. Either way I will die. But until that time I will live each day to the fullest, helping others and looking for joy for myself. Take care. Steffi
